At same time, many ageing nations will boost their own populations by 10-15% in 30 years, absorbing younger workers from poorer nations (legally or not). Providing needed workers, driving economic growth and extra tax revenues - on which future health and social care will depend. https://t.co/aXPRpZgMl0

As I predicted, large scale migration already an unstoppable, global force, powerful enough to break governments and fuel extremists. 1 billion will move from fields to cities in next 30 years, of which 100m will cross borders legally or illegally, fleeing conflicts and poverty. https://t.co/ijiY0tsqpW

As EU announces today a plan to ban all petrol and diesel vehicle sales from 2035, it is reminder once again how major actions against climate change can be triggered in minutes at very little cost to governments. Just by changing rules. As I have often said, expect many more! https://t.co/9Q8iVrOnK5

I predicted some years back that despite all the smart talk by many central banks that they were targeting 2% inflation, that they would tolerate far higher before raising interest rates, as has happened. But interest rates near zero (or even negative) just added fuel to fire.

Interest rate spike not caused only by energy. Never in history have interest rates been allowed to stay so much lower than inflation for so long. Central banks so scared of deflation following crash 2008-11, then more bad news eg COVID. Usually rise and fall in step. U.K. figs: https://t.co/V222aLg5tW

As I predicted, this particular energy price spike triggered by Russia’s war is a shorter term issue. Lesson of history is markets adapt, often at astonishing speed. Megatrends more powerful than events in transforming future, however huge events may appear at the time eg COVID. https://t.co/mde5wMF4z3

Omicron: any COVID variant where cases doubling in 48 hours is a major threat even if hospital admissions / deaths turn out lower than Delta. It means potentially 20 days to go from 1000 cases to 1m. Or 8 days to go from 1m to 16m. See latest Denmark hospital admissions data. https://t.co/6aZG0ZHaMJ

Omicron COVID early data continues to indicate explosive infectiousness but less risk per person infected of them becoming very sick compared to Delta. S Africa = young population with high previous delta infections so more data needed from other nations to map their own futures.

Additional important early Omicron data re lower than expected % severe illness. But HOW early are reports? Other data suggests Omicron may have spread for longer period than realised in which case data here may be slightly more reliable than otherwise. https://t.co/n3I3EWLkzH
More important early stage Omicron reports from S African hospital doctors on front line suggesting lower than expected % with severe breathing problems. https://t.co/H6symzXbvE

Important early Omicron data: Numbers of patients in Gauteng S Africa testing positive is high, and rising v fast, but mostly among people who are in with other conditions. Lower % positives are on oxygen and even lower % in ITU compared to what they saw with early stage Delta. https://t.co/uwHvcsuvMg

More important data in Omicron: cases rising faster in S Africa in Omicron wave than Delta, but not (yet) reflected in similar rate rise in deaths. See other early data / doctor reports showing that so far most cases in hospital are mild. https://t.co/C721PeLA8h

Here is some important data re Omicron: younger children in Tshwane, S Africa higher % of cases detected in hospital. But most of admissions on this chart were for reasons other than COVID. https://t.co/QFaYiTSSvv
